Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk pki-base
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: pki-core bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: Red Hat Certificate System is an enterprise software system designed to manage enterprise public key infrastructure (PKI) deployments. PKI Core contains fundamental packages required by Red Hat Certificate System, which comprise the Certificate Authority (CA) subsystem. The pki-core packages have been upgraded to upstream version 10.1, which provides a number of bug fixes and enhancements over the previous version, including: Upgraded the RESTeasy framework to a higher version. As a result, among other things, the interceptors server code implements the JAX-RS 2.0 API. Modified the Tomcat framework to use the systemd service unit files to start instead of the system V initialization scripts. This involved adding new Dogtag systemd unit files. Updated the REST API interface to use standard HTTP return codes under various operations. Also, added paging support to most search operations. Added new REST API interfaces for managing certificate profiles on the CA, including methods to manage profiles, extensions to the pki command-line tool to perform these operations, and a new method to provide enrollment templates to end-entity users for specific profiles. Improved the pki command-line tool, which involved organizing the pki commands according to the target of the performed operation. The previously used forms of the pki commands are still available to ensure backward compatibility. (BZ#1108303) This update also fixes the following bugs: The pki-core components are not supported on the little-endian variant of IBM Power Systems architecture. Previously, this architecture was not present on the ExcludeArch line of the pki-core spec file. Consequently, pki-core attempted to build on the little-endian variant of IBM Power Systems architecture hosts. This update adds the architecture to the ExcludeArch line, and pki-core no longer attempts to build on it. (BZ#1117073) Previously, the CA incorrectly altered its encoding for the CertificateIssuerName class when issuing certificates. As a consequence, the CA did not trust any of the internal certificates it issued. The underlying source code has been modified to ensure that the encoding for the distinguished name (DN) of the issuer and the DN of the subject is the same as the encoding for the CA certificates. Now, the CA trusts the certificates it issues as expected. (BZ#1151147) Previously, pki-core required the Secure Sockets Layer version 3 (SSLv3) protocol ranges to communicate with 389-ds-base. However, recent changes to the 389-ds-base packages disabled the default use of SSLv3 and enforced using protocol ranges supported by secure protocols, such as the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. As a consequence, the CA failed to install during an IdM server installation. This update adds TLS-related parameters to the server.xml file of the CA to fix this problem, and running the "ipa-server-install" command now installs the CA as expected. (BZ#1158410) Previously, certain pki-core shell scripts did not work as expected when invoked by running the systemctl process. The source code for the shell scripts has been modified, and they now work as expected. (BZ#1165351) In addition, this update adds the following enhancement: When the pkispawn tool uses an external CA, it does not add any X.509 version 3 (X.509 v3) extensions to the certificate signing request (CSR) to signify to the CA that the request is for a subordinate CA. This update adds the "pki_req_ext_add", "pki_req_ext_oid", "pki_req_ext_critical", and "pki_rq_ext_data" configuration parameters that can be used to add an extra request extension to the CSR of a CA signing certificate. Note that the parameters are available only in cases where an external CA is used and that you can add only one extension. (BZ#790924) Users of pki-core are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
